choices.A: Run the CQD User Feedback (Rate My Call) Report.
choices.F: Install the Power BI connector for Call Quality Dashboard (CQD).
choices.D: Upload a file to the Reporting Labels page.
choices.C: Upload a file to the Tenant Data Upload page.

discussion.content: I agree with B,C, but also F wouldn´t be that bad as it really helps looking at the data in the pbi templates.

comments.content: Installing connector would be just one step while dashboarding etc would still be pending. While BC would give access to web CQD data at least. One can create dashboards and graph there as well, not in a single page like PowerBi but its doable

questions.question_text:
In the Microsoft Call Quality Dashboard, you discover an increasing trend of poor-quality calls.
You need to implement a solution to identify problematic sites.
Which two actions should you perform? Each correct answer presents part of the solution.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BC
Lets look at the answers

A - doesn't make sense there is no policy assigned
D - EntepriseVoice is required, soo this option is off the table
E - There is already assigned the same number, and the question says it doesnt work, soo its's unnecessary to write the same wrong command

For me the most likely answers are B and C
C&E correct answer

Selected Answer: BC
A.D.E isn't correct answer
but B and C is correct

This question is obsolate.
Use Set-CsPhoneNumberAssignment.

Perhaps C & D "were" the correct answer. 
C: SIP address with tel: and E.164 format. 
D: Telephone number in E.164 format.
Why D??? Enterprise Voice should enabled or not?

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft Teams Phone deployment. The 613 7010 5XXX phone number range is allocated to the Session Border Controller (SBC).
A user named User1 is configured as shown in the following exhibit.
//IMG//

User1 reports that when an external caller attempts to call the phone number of User1, the external caller receives an error message.
User1 can make outbound calls, but no caller ID appears.
Which two commands should you run to resolve the issues? Each correct answer presents part of the solution.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

HOTSPOT -
You are deploying Microsoft Teams Calling Plans to three users as shown in the following table.
//IMG//

You need to resolve the issues.
What should you assign to each user? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

discussion.content:
User1: Missing EV and needo enabled by assigning a phone number
User2: Dial Plan and its normalization rules to route 4 digits ext numbers
User3: Missing Phone System License??

In the Teams client, the dial pad enables users to access Public Switched Telephone Network (PSTN) functionality. The dial pad is available for users with a Phone System license, provided they're configured properly. All of the following conditions must be met for the dial pad to appear:

The user has a Teams license assigned.
The user has a Teams Phone System (MCOEV) license assigned.
The user has Microsoft Calling Plan, Operator Connect, or is enabled for Direct Routing.
The user has Enterprise Voice enabled.
The user is homed online and not in Skype for Business on-premises.
The user has Teams Calling Policy enabled with AllowPrivateCalling = True.

so user 1 : calling policy
user 2:dial plan
user 3: phone system license

User 1 : A Phone number
User 2: Dial Plan
User 3 : Phone System License

User 2 have E5 (including Phone System License), so it could be missing Dial plan to dial 4-digit number

User 1: Bad question, not even mentioning how EV is configured which is usually the main reason why dialpad is missing. I would choose phone number from the selection.
User 2: Dialpad
User 3: Phone system license

'A phone number' because its missing an even with the right calling policy dial pad wont appear if its missing a phone number, 'A dial plan' is the only option that can allow 4 digit dialing , 'A MS 365 Phone System license' is a requirement to have MS Teams with MS E3 license or switch to E5

questions.question_text:
Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution.
After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen.
Your company uses configuration profiles to manage Microsoft Teams-certified IP phones. The Standard configuration profile is applied to the IP phones.
The help desk receives reports that several user phones fail to lock automatically after the timeout period.
You need to verify whether the configuration profile is applied to the problematic phones.
Solution: From Devices in the Microsoft Teams admin center, you select Phones, select the Configuration profiles tab, select Standard Phone Policy, and select Assigned devices.
Does this meet the goal?

discussion.content: Selecting 'Assigned Devices' only gives you a count of the number of devices the profile is assigned to, it doesn't list the devices, therefore the answer (No), is correct.

Answer is correct. This is saying that it goes deeper in the config profile tab. There is a previous question where it only mentions config profile tab. and in that one the answer is yes. 
so, both are correct
Duplicate question here https://www.examtopics.com/exams/microsoft/ms-720/view/25/
No this is wrong, this is exactly where you got to adjust the lock settings on the device. Its literally the first item when you goto the configuration profile.

Selected Answer: C
To me is C. A option doesn´t specify that is for emergency calls.

Selected Answer: A
To ensure that emergency calls placed to 9911 are routed to 911 in a Microsoft Teams Phone deployment, you should configure an outbound PSTN number translation rule.

o ensure that emergency calls placed to 9911 are routed to 911 in a Microsoft Teams Phone deployment, you should configure an outbound PSTN number translation rule.==A
Option C, an emergency call routing policy, and option D, an emergency calling policy, are both used to control how emergency calls are handled within the Microsoft Teams Phone system. However, they do not provide the ability to modify the called number before it is sent to the PSTN.

Selected Answer: C
The explanation is C actually...

Selected Answer: A
All of those saying C is the correct answer - Nothing in this questions states this is using Direct Routing. Note that Emergency call routing policies apply only to Direct Routing--they do not apply to Calling Plans or Operator Connect.

comments.content: Trunk translation rules also only apply to direct routing though, so by your logic it cant be A either.

discussion.content: configure "an emergency call routing policy" is the correct answer

Selected Answer: C
C is answer for me as well.

Selected Answer: C
Emergency call routing policy

Selected Answer: A
unclear question as this could be achieved using A, B, or C... for me most elegant would be dialplan manipulation to remove 9. Same could be achieved using C and emergency dial mask. In case of Direct routing, I would say A is easiest as it does not require assignment of additional policies to users.
C is answer

choices.A: an outbound PSTN number translation rule

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft Teams Phone deployment that is used in the United States.
You need to ensure that emergency calls placed to 9911 are routed to 911.
What should you configure?
